body: I'm curious about some of you think of this story. Personally I think it's fake, as it's only referenced at the beginning of Matthew and Luke, the latter clearly being a later addition to the original Luke. Nowhere else do any of the writers show any indication of knowing about a virgin birth, including in the rest of Matthew and Luke. Additionally, some of the oldest manuscripts of Matthew read "Joseph begat Jesus" and many current references to Joseph are "Jesus's father" in the oldest manuscripts. The genealogy in Matthew makes no sense if Mary conceived as a virgin, as it shows Joseph's line of descent, not Mary's, and the whole point is to show how Jesus came from the Davidic line. I have a theory however about why this story was added: the faithless church fathers, instead of believing because it is self-evident, either newly interpreted Isaiah 7:14 as messianic, or it was actually put there by Matthew, but the church fathers, due to a mistranslation in the LXX, thought it meant virgin when it was actually young woman (the same word is used for both). Either way, they lacked faith and only cared about creating a religious system to control people, and authored this story to "prove" it right. Ironically, the original Hebrew prophecy is only correct if Joseph is Jesus's (biological) father. It's also possible that they wanted to introduce elements of pagan legends, though harmless ones in this case (unless you take it to the extreme of worshiping Mary).

By "most people" I assume you mean most people attending Authorized King James 1611 Only churches, because no one outside of those circles actually believes later copies are more reliable. The arguments that the older texts in our possession are erratic and corrupted make sense theoretically, but that doesn't mean it is the case, only that it *could* be. But we can be certain it is not so because:

* All quotes from early church fathers conform with the older texts; not a single one is aware of the later Byzantine text type

* All early translations conform to the earlier texts

* Internal evidence is clear that the later readings are the edited versions; they tend to smooth out the sentences and make it sound more natural, and sometimes insert later theology into the text. A scribe would want to make the text look better, not worse.

In the end I feel like insisting on the virgin birth just breaks the original messianic prophecy which says young woman, not virgin, as a translation error in the Septuagint implies. And the story could then be used to claim that Jesus can't be the messiah because he wasn't actually descended from David, as the genealogy shows Joseph's line of descent, not Mary's.
